description:
I don't entirely know how to explain my love of this place, other than to say every time I've been in I've ended up having one of the most interesting night I've had in a while. 

Also, when I was in once with two guy friends who were clearly a bit too drunk, the female bartender pulled me aside to make sure I was okay and felt safe. She had no way of knowing that I've been friends with them for most of my life and it meant a lot to me that she had been keeping an eye out and bothered to check-in. Already loved the bar by then but that helped seal the deal.
author: Beth S.

description:
This bar looks like a teenage boy got a big allowance and decided to decorate his bedroom with fish tanks with fake fish, disco balls, zebra print wallpaper, black lights and so many other amazing yet aesthetically conflicting things.

With all of the overly fancy bars in SF these days, you have to appreciate the existence of EZ5. I hate it but love it and I hope it never closes or, better yet, changes it's decor.
author: Nick K.

description:
Their jukebox got updated! I was pleasantly surprised...played my jams all night! Friendly people and great staff! 

My go to spot if I needed a beer after work. Always fun times at EZ5
author: Sam Y.

description: Now this bar, is a hidden gem. I've been coming here for quite some time. The staff is super friendly and the owner (mama) is always a joy to be around. There is music and crazy dance lights and with the drinks flowing, it's never a dull moment or a bad time.
author: Katlyn H.

description: Ez5 has been my husbands go to spot for years now. Such a friendly staff, great atmosphere. The place is unpretentious and uniquely itself. They've got beers and a bunch of liquor but not really a fancy cocktail menu. It's more chill than cocktails. Come here for a beer, a well drink, and listen to some tunes with friends. The place has a good amount of seating and would be great for groups.  Extra stars for the zebra wall paper.
author: Veronica L.

description: Randomly walking down Kearny and saw a blinking light for this bar. The drinks are cheap. Definitely will be coming back to this place.
author: Natalie S.

description: Becoming one of my hangouts in the city.  Finding a local crowd mixed with some random tourists.  Nice bartenders and cool vibe.  Love their extended happy hour M-F until 8pm!
author: Paul S.

description:
Needed a place to pause between an A's day game and an evening alumni event. Good bartender, good company at the bar -- took one patron's advice and got a $3 Sapporo. Got tips on some good places to eat in Chinatown from the fellow who replaced him on the barstool to my left -- surprisingly the Broadway/Man Kee/Finn Cafe did not come up.
Not a true dive bar for two reasons: Room is too shiny and moderne to be a dive, and the conversation pits discourage the sort of free-flowing conversations that are the hallmark of a dive bar. (Further, a total of ONE cute girl arrived while I was there, while a couple of 4s who thought they were 8s eventually emerged from the pits). But if you don't want to mix with the hoi polloi, perhaps the pits are for you.
Mama monitors the bar, while Papa monitors Mama (seemingly).
author: Michael D.

description:
I've been here a few times for HH in the past as the bartenderess were eye-candy, and the place was dim but full of locals. I didn't mind and went out of the way to go here.
Nowadays both are reversed and nothing wrong with that, coughs. As a result, the place feels out of the way. Kudos for carrying Galaga though.
 
Still worthy of a stop if it's convenient. The drinks are priced cheaper than many places though a bit watered down.
author: Peter L.

description:
SUPER divey bar located in Chinatown. It's really oddly decorated, but if you're used to Chinese homes, the decor might not surprise you too much.

I came for happy hour with some coworkers and they have some pretty good happy hour deals. Definitely not my kind of bar, but with $5 wine, I wouldn't be completely opposed to coming back.
author: Jessie L.

description:
While it's not the "Chinese Ultra-lounge in the FiDi" as my friend once called it, EZ5 is a good after-work hole in the wall kind of watering hole that really grows on you. 

The decor is truly a mish-mash of things - think orange walls juxtaposed by leopard print but it's all about the service here and specifically - MaMa, the owner. She is truly the most warm and hospitable host who makes sure you're having a good time. Armed with free jello shots, she gives them out to patrons (you can buy them too) who lap them up like kids with candy. We made up a game - jello shot jenga (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ez5-san-francisco?select=OYYeCtPKGv6Vo9uTQaMxhw#OYYeCtPKGv6Vo9uTQaMxhw) with our stash. Truly fun. 

EZ5 is an unapologetically unpretentious watering hole. Just come in and have fun; nobody judges here. Plus if you're hungry, you can have Chinese food delivered from New Hong Kong Menu across the street. MaMa cool with that.
author: Jon L.

description:
I stopped in for a happy hour and the place was rocking.  I enjoyed the location on the alley and the front couch area was roomy enough to hand out without being claustrophobic.  The bar area itself was a bit dark and the blue glow made it feel more like a nightclub than a lounge/cocktail bar.

The low point was the Manhattan I ordered - simply average (a bit watery due to the preparation). 

The prices, however, were a complete surprise.  2 glasses of wine and a manhattan came to $16?  That didn't seem right, but I guess the HH prices were truly that low.  So no complaints.
author: Andreas H.

description: Great happy hour specials, and the bar is spotless!  Service was fine, but not very friendly.
author: Violet G.

description:
I came here last week late in the evening and the place was quiet.  Based on some of the reviews, the best time to come is after work, Monday through Friday.

Anyways, the bartender and owners were really nice.  The drinks were competitively priced and they have $1 jello shots!  I saw turntables, but unfortunately the music was being played from the jukebox. 

I would definitely come here again next time I'm in the area, but just after work hours.
author: Eddie F.

description:
I dropped into EZ5 to watch the NBA playoffs. First off, I never knew there was a dive bar here. Secondly, I didn't know this place was really cool! 

The game was on Wednesday and the place was pretty empty. I loved it! It was like watching the game at home without having to commit to a six pack of one particular beer (you know.. Because I have commitment issues). INSTEAD! I was able to buy drafts for the very reasonable price of $5 per pint. I was switching it up between Sierras and Pyramids which are both solid choices.

There were several TV's to watch the game and TONS of couch space. Talk about feeling like home. It'd be great for groups as large as 7-10 people.

This dive bar has no frills and no food so check that appetite at the door. 

Bottom line:  Very solid establishment. I'm going to come here for all my sports watching going forward.
author: Chris W.

description:
Awesome joint in the FiDi/Chinatown border... Definitely great for a large group... The hostesses were friendly... My only complaint was the lack of pickle juice for a pickle back... 

Oh and please pick a larger selection of songs, I heard the some songs 3 times... Unless there was a jukebox I didn't see?
author: Nathan D.

description:
This review is way, way overdue. I have been coming to the EZ5 for the past 10+ years, & have ALWAYS experienced great service, a calm, no-hassle, relaxed atmosphere, good, reasonably-priced drinks, & a warm & welcoming attitude from the Owners, Kam & Annie.

It is one of the only bars in the city where I have never seen or experienced any "hassle" or had to deal with any customers who had over-imbibed. In short, it is a great neighborhood bar, with a  great happy hour, Guinness on tap & a very good house wine selection. They train their bartenders & wait staff well, & service is always top-notch.

If you've not been to EZ5, stop by Commercial Street & Kearny, between Sacramento & Clay, give it a try, & write a review. I will be interested to see if my experience holds true with you; a great place for cocktails & to "KB&MO" (Kick Back & Mellow Out) at any time of the evening!
author: Richard B.

description: My favorite bar in the financial district. Full of regulars with a great atmosphere and the owners are awesome.
author: Jack O.

description:
I'm not sure a bar can get more awesome for me. Friendly bar owners, the place was empty and they were playing some awesome old school hip hop. Thank you and yes please. Some people HATE empty bars, I on the other hand love it. I love getting drinks when I want 'em, I love when the music is awesome and you can hear it and occasionally break out in dance moves, and I love not waiting for a bathroom. All of those things went down here.

The place has a long bar with some couches readily available for your seating pleasures and of course an old school Pac Man/Galaga game. Can I get a hell yeah? This place is a dive without the dive. Does that make sense? I hope so.

The check in offer of a $4 Fernet shot got my homies pretty drunk but, I switched it to Jameson and it was all good. Only one per customer ladies and gents.

Keep playing that hip hop, stay away crowds, and I'll be there all night long. ***

Def peep it.

*** When I'm in SF once a year.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
So, I originally found this little gem a few years back while taking in a happy hour at a neighboring business. We were eating appetizers and sipping some drinks when the bartender at this business (which will still remain nameless) asked us if we wanted to do a shot. Our answer was yes but what happened next was very unexpected and completely took us off guard. I thought for sure that he was going to slide some shots across the bar but instead we slid out the back door and across the alley to EZ5. Great find!

Small, clean and divey describe EZ5 perfectly. The staff is sweet and the drinks are strong. The crowd can be a bit shifty but it only adds to the charm of the place. They are running a Yelp check-in offer for a $4 shot of Fernet but they have been known to substitute if you ask nicely and top it off with a little wink. Throw a few bucks into the Pac Man machine and you have a pretty solid night ahead of you!

Keep this place in mind when the other joints in the neighborhood are bursting at the seams with overpriced drinks... you'll like. I promise.
author: Brad B.

description:
Why yes, I am a fan. $5 beers (all beers, so pick a good one), $4 Fernet shot check-in offer, quick friendly service and divey-chic interior left me in a state of tipsy bliss. Definitely a good, upbeat, unpretentious vibe - all around fun. Oh, and 4-8 happy hour is a generous timeslot!

I must have just missed the start of karaoke when I left, which I will likely regret forever.
author: Emily C.

description: If I can give below zero stars I would off. Worst customer service. Ultra rude people. Drinks way over priced. I would stay away at all cost! This is the first time I ever write a bad review about a business because I tend to look at the best in life. But the way I was treated was very rude and shitty.
author: K H.

description:
My friend and I were in San Francisco over the weekend and found this place randomly. The ambience seemed cool and we decided to walk in. Everything seemed nice, and a gentleman came to take our order. But we were not ready to order anything just yet and said we needed some time. One minute later a girl approached us and started harassing and pressuring us to buy something immediately (I believe she was another bartender). We told her we were going to order something, and we needed more time to decide. However, she did not leave us alone and kept pushing us to get up and order something. We were not in the mood to argue, so we got up and ordered some drinks. We finished the drinks in 10 minutes, and then left, since that girl ruined our mood.
It started to hit us later how rude she was towards us, it was such an unusual and weird experience that really made us leave EZ5 with the worst possible memory and experience.
author: Shahin S.

description:
A few of my buddies have been regulars at EZ5 for over 10 years. They know everyone who works there. Naturally, this small hole in the wall Chinatown bar has become a regular hang out spot on Friday and Saturday nights. We've celebrated countless birthdays at EZ5, but really....you don't need any excuse to have a gathering at EZ5. 

You'll be welcome with open arms by owner Annie, who will start passing out jello shots to everyone. She'll also randomly pull out the coconut bra and grass skirt and make you wear it just for fun. She'll come out from behind the bar and dance when she feels like it or serve herself up a shot and join in on the fun. She'll make you feel right at home. Annie is the super cool aunt you wish you had. 

DJ is always spinning the best hip hop and R&B. I like the old school stuff. Can I hear some Wu-Tang C.R.E.A.M.? He makes it happen. Last song of the night will be some slow jam....yeahhhhh flashing you back to your first jr. high dance. LOL! Good tunes and cool ass DJ. Another reason to love EZ5. 

The drinks are standard. Honestly, I go more for the fun than the drinks. It's always a good night out. You can count on that.
author: Liv A.

description:
I don't usually have any type of issue with a place offering free food (crackers, cheese, chips, salami, etc) at happy hour, but this place has the worst wait service I have experienced in a while.

My group of probably 7 or 8 went for a drink after work and having never been there, I was impressed with the lounge-y vibe, good music, being greeted by the owner (or manager?) and being seated immediately. We were just going to grab a drink at the bar, and this is where things got weird.  

Not sure if our waitress was new, but she didn't seem to understand that we wanted to order at the bar and sit down. So we told her we would do 3 separate tabs (for those leaving earlier than others) and she became super flustered and kept asking for everyone's card, also neglecting to tell us that it's $20 minimum on cards until after we had our first round. It's her one job to accommodate customers and it seemed to be too overwhelming.

After having my first drink of gin and tonic (which lacked strength) I was slammed with questions about if I was paying with cash or credit, and, as stated above, we had already told her our payment situation when we sat down. When we were leaving, she repeatedly asked how we were going to tip her, in cash or on our cards, which I thought was incredibly rude and presumptuous. 

Overall, the place is cool, but the management needs to re-think their waitress choices.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Visited this pub with great singers and live performance since 3 years ago but was totally disappointed with their service that has got from bad to worse.

There are 3 performances every night at 945pm, 1045pm and 1145pm. Every entrance fee costs NT700 from Sunday to Thursday and NT800 on Friday and Saturday. You will be given 2 vouchers for ordering of light snacks and non-alcoholic/alcoholic beverages upon entrance. 

While it is reasonable for the crew to take in more customers to watch performance when all tables are occupied, it is unreasonable when you are required to 'squeeze' yourself at some corner or stand in between tables, not having a tiny space to put your drinks/snacks at all. It is a shame that service crew is usually ignorant with a 'i-couldn't-care-less' attitude when you approach them to ask for help. 

Advice: If you really want to get a hang of it, do visit this place on weekdays only. 

If you can't get to this place before 8.30pm-ish to get a table/ can't reserve a table because you don't own a local mobile number/could reserve a table but couldn't make it to the place before 9pm, I would suggest to just give it a pass, unless you could endure standing at the same spot for 3 hours and not ordering anything having paid NT700 or NT800.
author: May F.

description:
Karaoke? No? But it's time! Confused.

The couches, the sparkle lighting sharing shadows with bottled specimens illuminatin' straight outta Aliens (Game over, man; game over!), the never-ending stream of b-boy jams, phresh beats and five buck beers means I should love this monstrous amalgamation of everything and anything.

Yet, it doesn't sit incredibly well. Can't drink the hops and as such, my weakly-poured well wodka with a brown lime is $7, just because it's a tall. Did I miss the 4-8p HH? Were we moments from the much-laureled self-sung songstar showdown? Could it be possible my two hour visit to EZ5 hit every doldrum in its promising nightly rundown?

'Twas the company (not the tall vodka) that kept my spirits high. Attempting much while mastering none, this alley lounge casts a wide net in a barren kiddie pool.
author: Damien S.

description:
Awesome spot to relax after a long day!! It is hard to beat the service, strength of drinks, and the atmosphere. 

Whether you are looking for a couple drinks with your buddies after work, or a night with a large group, this is the spot!!  There are always snacks, drink deals, and if you are lucky, a few jello shots!!  

99% of the time you are able to request music to be played by the dj, and really make the spot your own!!

A hidden gem in the city!!!!
author: Jesse K.

description:
This place totally reminds me of an ex-strip club.  The red lights, the booth seating.. something just screams "strip club."  

Oh and did I mention, it's surrounded by "massage parlors."  The only reason why I have quotations around it is because these massage parlors look completely closed down.... boarded up.. newspapers covering the facade.. long hallways that lead to who knows where.. and there are neon lights everywhere...  I'll let you put those components together.. sketch huh?

Well on the bright side, their drinks are super cheap and super strong.  

There's generally not that many people there, but it can get kind of crowded on Fridays.  

Service... kind of rude and standoff-ish... 

Overall, not my favorite spot, but I guess it's a nice way to start off happy hour.
author: Cecilia S.

description:
First things first, this isn't a fancy place. It's a dive bar, and the crowd isn't always that great, but the reason I give this place 5 stars is because they care about and take care of their customers. 

I went here last week with a friend, wanting cheap booze and some good beats to dance to on a week night. Sure enough, the AMFs were flowing and the music was too. 

Now in all honesty, this only happened because I was stupid, but I had left my wallet and phone on the bar and was dancing with my girl, about three feet away, having a great time, and enjoying our night off. I glanced at the bar, and felt that instantaneous sobering feeling.. My wallet, and phone were gone. Adios Mother F**ker.
The expletives were flowing next as I ran out of the bar with my girl's phone, frantically signing into 'Find my iPhone' while simultaneously hating myself for being so careless. I had been asking for it... until, the owner (I assume she's the owner, but she's the sweetest lady) came chasing after me to tell me that she'd seen my phone and wallet, and knew I was having a good time, and had pulled it behind the bar. 

I almost cried. She was looking out for me, and knew I wasn't exactly 100%, or taking care of my stuff. An owner like that, who cares about the people who drop by, and who goes out of their way to guarantee that nothing goes afoul during the night, A+++ in my book!

Will definitely be back on my next night off!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
It's okay. I came here for a work event, otherwise, I probably would've never discovered this spot on my own. It's on the fence of the Financial District and Chinatown. The outside is unassuming and the bar is located halfway down a random alleyway. Once inside though, it did "feel like a bar."

Interesting choice of music (lots of 80's; lots of Madonna).Drinks are super cheap (esp for being so close to financial). Crowd is the after-work happy hour crowd.

Okay bar, although there are definitely better ones in the area.
author: Yanni L.

description:
Crackin at 8, but place is way too overpriced. I like whiskey, so I ordered a Macallan 12 neat... paid like a Macallan 25.

There's a zebra-print wall. reminds of me what an 80s porno movie set would look like. I wouldn't recommend it or go back myself. But if everything is too packed, and you want a place to lounge (with a hooker probably), then go here.

Peace!
author: Farhan K.

description: Strong drinks and friendly staff.  Solid spot.
author: Chris S.

description: This place is cool.  I didn't know it existed.  The decor is a little cheap and tacky but the DJ spins old school hip hop.  The waiters are quick and efficient.  I think the drinks should be cheaper for a dive bar.  This place is casual - jeans, t-shirt, sneakers - all ok.  Mixed crowd and it happened to be wig night.  Fun people, cool place.
author: Chris L.

description:
Completely dug this place. 

My boyfriend and I were on a mini-break in SF and went to R&G for dinner. The wait was going to be 40 minutes and the bar was packed. The hostess recommended EZ5 which was just across the street and down the block. 
It was easily the highlight of our night. The bartenders were super attentive and quick with a refill, we instantly met some great people at the bar and joined their game of domino's (which i won!), the music (although not my normal taste) was perfect for the setting: upbeat without being obnoxious. The crowd was really diverse and you really got the vibe that everyone was mellow and just down to have a good time and a few drinks.
author: Chantell L.

description:
If I could do it all over again, I'd remain in the Gallaga stool and sip on San Francisco's finest. It's on the list of "the charm of San Francisco can be found here." Turn down that alley and you might think you're in Hong Kong, or Shanghai. 

Maybe this could be categorized as a dive bar because of the lurches at the bar that are there on the regular, and the floors were technically sticky. But there's a spacious Asian Lounge feel to this place that is welcome for a party of 20 to descend upon the place. But just know... Mama will get you Shoes Off Drunk.
author: Jon A.

description:
Nice decor, quick service from the 2-3 bartenders even during happy hour. Definitely a kick-back spot for diverse young professionals. A good handful of beer selection on tap. For the sports fans however, there are only 3 screens of average size so not great for large parties because of limited stool seating. The day I came, they had $3 Jägermeister shots!! Win!

Overall - If you are looking for a budget dive bar with a festive young crowd, definitely a nice place in Chinatown to check out.
author: Dat P.

description:
Disclaimer: they will not let you use the $4 Jameson shot yelp offer when checking in here! 

I went here on a Monday evening on the way to City Lights bookstore. There weren't many people there, but the decor was more upscale than expected looking from the outside. It was happy hour and we were served promptly (without checking IDs, i look like a teenager). The 3 dollar Sierra Nevadas are right up my alley. My boyfriend and I left to go to a book signing and returned about an hour later. 

The lady (who I presume is the owner) YELLED that it was not happy hour anymore. We said that was fine, we didn't understand why she was yelling at us. I tried to claim my offer advertised on here and she just laughed and said "that was last week." Though no specified dates were on the offer. After that we wanted to leave. She insisted (very rudely) we had one more beer than we knew we did and overcharged us for everything we ordered. 

The first time we visited we gave her a 25% tip so we did not understand why she became so rude, did not let us claim out yelp offer, and overcharged us. We were not drinking heavily and were very polite throughout it all, but...

We will not be returning. 1 star for nice happy hour and for the fact you can't give 0. One if the worst bar experiences I have had. I'd only recommend to the people looking for a place that doesn't check IDs.
author: Amy G.

description:
Apparently, upon entering EZ5 I checked-in on my mobile interwebz location device and left this tip:

"Love this joint. $20 cc minimum, but I care not. Best."

But for why, R Felly? Why the best?

Run-on sentence style:

For a gal from a city she loves and adores with all her heart but is an admittedly "third tier" US metro, places like EZ5 are the places I live to see and experience when I venture to big-ass, "first-tier" American cities. 

To expound:

I can't get Burmese food in MKE. I can't go to a weird Irish pub with seven stools that serves margaritas and has karaoke. Homeless folks don't walk backwards down the sidewalks with blankets on their heads here in the Mil. I also can't go to a Chinese dive bar/club in an alley complete with a mama and a killer vibe. EZ5 is and has all aforementioned things, which is why I loved it so.

Some people think some things are sketchy. I'm learning that sketch not only doesn't bother me as much as some, but that I also seem to seek out a bit of grit from time to time. Good for the soul, in my opinion.

PLUS THIS PLACE WAS NOT EVEN THAT SKETCHY AT ALL.

Lagunitas IPA and some whiskey and this girl's set. I don't know. Good company, unique and fun vibe, upbeat yet not over-the-top, and just all-around fun.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Happy Hour + Cheap Drinks + DJ Spinning Top 40s/Hip-Hop/R&B =  UH-OH :X

John Colins is normally my go-to spot for HH but the last couple of times, my friends and I just weren't feeling the vibe, not to mention the blaring downtempo music which made it impossible to talk with each other.  

Feening for an after work drink and change of scenery, I decided to ask my trusty alkie friend (I mean that in the nicest possible way) for HH suggestions. He gave me 5-6 suggestions (outside the norm of Dada, 111 Minna, Eve, and 183 Proof) with EZ5 being one of them.

At first glance of his text message, I was thinking, "WTH is EZ5?!?!" Although my friend mentioned that EZ5 is crackin' on Thursdays and Fridays, we decided to take a chance and come here for HH on Wednesday, January 12th. 

EZ5 is tucked away in an alley (across from R&G Lounge) that separates Chinatown and FIDI. From the outside, one would think that EZ5 belongs in the outskirts of the Sunset or Richmond Area with the opaque orange tinted windows with black paw prints and bright fluorescent signage.

D R I N K S:
HH is Monday - Friday, 4 PM-8 PM. Beer and wine are $3/glass. Regular cocktails are $7-9 depending on your liquor selection. $20 minimum for CC's.

I had a Hendrick's Tonic ($9) and a Tanqueray Tonic ($7 - made by accident) both of which were STRONG! *happy dance*

The bartender was very friendly. It was a slow last night and she went around asking people if they needed another around which was nice of her. 

C R O W D:
The crowd was mixed and pretty chill for Wednesday HH; young professionals in their 20s, corporate banker types, some tourists and ones who seem to be "regulars".

Based on other Yelpers' reviews, I can imagine the crowd being predominately Asian on Friday and Saturday nights. 

M U S I C:
Other than Mercury Lounge, EZ5 is the only bar/lounge that plays Top 40s, Hip Hop, and R&B during HH which is HUGEEEE plus in my book! There are resident DJs on Tuesdays (all genres), Thursdays (Hip Hop, R&B & Old School), Fridays (Hip Hop & R&B) and Saturdays (Hip-Hop & R&B). Monday is Karaoke night. 

That night, we met Benson who helps DJ from time to time. He was really nice, encouraged requests from us and even brought us to the meet the couple that owns EZ5. I'm normally the buzzed one running up to the DJ every SINGLE weekend screaming, "CAN YOU PLAY STEREO LOVEEEEE PUH-LEASE???" This time I wasn't drunk AND I didn't even have to get up because Benson was nice enough to come and ask what we wanted to hear.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R:
Upon walking into EZ5, I didn't know what to make of the décor. It was eclectic and funky; tangerine walls, colorful random hand paintings, tchotchkes hanging on the walls, a 70s disco ball and tacky foil garland draping the ceiling posts.

There's seating for 10-12 at the bar, 3 booths, and large square ottomans between the bar and the booths. 

The music was the perfect volume; loud enough to make you want to bob your head, but not loud to the point where you have to scream across the room (like other bars/lounges) just so the person next to you can hear you.  

Other Yelpers mentioned a dance floor? If they clear out the center ottomans, there is a large pathway to the restroom between the bar and the booths, but I wouldn't exactly call that a dance floor per say. There's also a small space in front of the DJ booth, the size of a cubicle which I guess others are referring to as the "dance floor"? Well in any event, when you're drunk anywhere can be your dance floor right? Gawd knows when I am, I turn the couches in the clubs to "my" dance floor. :X

P A R K I N G:
On weekdays, easy metered parking before 6 PM (at the 4-6 PM tow away zone). These spots are taken very quickly, so get there by 5:45 PM to snag a space and then sit in your car until 6 PM. 

On the weekends after 10 PM, street parking is relatively easy to find as most neighboring businesses have closed by then. 

If you can't find street parking, The Portsmouth Square Garage is located a block away on Kearny/Washington streets and the rate is $3/hour. 

The funky ambiance and décor aside, I really like EZ5 for a HH spot with awesome music. I WILL DEFINITELY BE BACK!!!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
For a Thursday night, this place was, as they say, poppin'...

Please allow me to paint a picture:
15 parched individuals wandered down Commercial St. following a company-sponsored happy hour looking for a place to "network". Fast forward five minutes and SoCo Lime shots are being hoisted into the air in a tipsy fervor against the 70s porno-esque backdrop of zebra print and bubbling neon water lamps.

Intrigued?

If not, at the very least, EZ5 has all the qualities of wondrous dive bar. You've got cheap and decent variety of drinks, you've got enough space to accommodate large parties, you've got friendly and attentive bartenders who were taking drink orders at our table seconds after arrival, and you've got Ms. Pac Man. Need I say more?
author: Nick W.

description:
For some reason every single bar in SF is a dive bar. I guess it must be trendy right now. EZ5 however, is not a dive bar and it actually stands out.

Before stepping inside I could have sworn this was a massage parlor. After entering I was still pretty sure someone would come up to me and ask if I wanted a foot massage. It looks like Quagmire's bedroom (Family Guy reference). I mean c'mon they have lava lamps! While the decor and ambiance are somewhat questionable, I must say I quite liked the place. Drinks are cheap and a check-in will get you a 4 dollar shot of Fernet Branca. Nice!

If you are getting tired of all that dive bar hipster mess, I recommend you check this place out!
author: Mikko A.

description:
bartender helped herself to a 35% tip on my credit card AFTER I TIPPED HER IN CASH. not cool

noticed it after checking my receipts this morning.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Despite tacky decor that seemed to come right out of a cheesy '80s sitcom, this place provided several hours of fun. Located on a side street alley in Chinatown, EZ5 still gave my group of friends plenty of room to dance!

Drinks were just okay, though there were also some freebies given from the bar, including Jell-O shots. Also were some smokers outside by the door, which wafted their smoke right on in to "breathe" for awhile. Mainly was great for getting to dance to good music at a dive bar.
author: Garett T.

description:
$4 Fernet shots and $5 beers. All night long. All. Night. Long. 

The interior of EZ5 is nothing to celebrate, but the prices are fabulous and the selection is nothing to scoff at. I had plenty of fun with my Sierra Nevadas and the dopey disco tunes they played all night in the red light. Also, the vinyl sofas? Genius. Just don't let your bare skin touch 'em. Ewies. 

The lady bartender was quick and sweet and the beers were cold. No crowd meant plenty of room for our large posse, and while some of us may have had one too many, it certainly didn't break the bank.
author: Hilary H.

description:
Maybe I hang out at extra sketchy places when looking for a dive, but my idea of a dive bar is maybe a little seedy and some place you wouldn't bring your frat buddie to. Some reviews had this as a dive bar.  This is NOT a dive bar.
The decor is nice and it's a a little dark, but the crowd seemed like a mix of convention tourists and frat boys that just got out of college and are letting loose from their bank jobs.
The crowd did not match the intended ambiance.  Hip hop + room full of financial analysts is the only way I can describe it.  Weird.
A little pricey for what you get and no credit card for under $25 (maybe was $20).  So, if you just want one drink, bring cash. 
We stayed for one drink and left.  Unless you work around here, no reason to make it a destination...unless you're "in town for the convention".

One plus, our waitress was nice.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Ten Reasons I love EZ5 and 1 reason I dont:

1. Jager chilling machine
2. Patron chilling machine
3. Cheap drinks
4. Stiff drinks
5. Awesome couch lounge area
6. Weird lil pirate fish tanks on way to bathroom
7. Dice
8. Poker/game machine thing that eats your money but you cant stop
9. Lived upstairs
10. DJs on weekends but not crazy loud

1. Not open 24/7
author: Christina S.

description: Love this place! Never too crowded and the owners man the bar.  They have unique beers/wines/sake, a TV, juke box and mini dance floor.  Great place!
author: Price L.

description:
I would describe this as a nicer dive bar.

2 big screen TVs that play local sports.

Cheap beers during happy hour.

Cute Bartender/Waitresses.  Friendly owner.

They allow you to bring in your own food.  Cheee!
author: Steven F.

description:
In my head, EZ5 = FUN TIMES!!!!

Yes, the decor is a little cheesy and it's a little bar with a dance floor & a DJ, but the patrons that go to this bar are usually pretty cool :)  And the owners and bartenders are extremely friendly and helpful!

 They do take reservations if you have a large party, so you get your own seating!

The parking usually isn't too hard.  I've never had to park more than a block away.  Usually you can find parking on the same street.

DO TRY THEIR LYCHEE MARTINI. MMMM :)

Ah. So many great memories, now if I could just remember them!
author: Peggy S.

description:
Love this place - me and my crew of 15 people went and had a B L A S T !!!! I called a week ahead and spoke to Tu, she was really cool and had reserved a table/area of us. 

We were late coming from the restaurant but they 're-arranged' some people and we had our space, a really on top of it what-can-I-getcha server. requested some music and danced from 9pm until after midnight. 

Great DJ, Great Cocktails and a Great Time!!
author: Rew C.

description:
Cheap happy hour and I can walk there from work. That is what makes it 4 stars.

Weird ambiance - you walk in through a metal bead door thing and it's kinda like a lounge? but the crowd does not match the bar. it seems like regular blue collar folk, and they all were watching sports. so the neon lights and decor clashed with the patrons. Whatever I'll still go back sometimes after work.
author: Kristin T.

description:
personally, one of my favorites in this area.
Annie, Michelle and staff are kind, genuine and all around pleasant people.

nice atmosphere, good vibes, relaxing ambience....
and Michelle alone is worth a star or two.

worth checking out, if only for a few cocktails~
author: Troy R.

description:
i've only been here twice but I gotta say...they were really nice. I always met nice people here as well so that's another plus.

is it the best bar in the city...not close. Is it the worst..again...not close.
its a great place to meet up before hitting the city hard or for a beer or two after work on a friday.

I'd go back...I think actually I will.
author: Dean M.

description:
Incredibly fun bar!!  I came here for a friend's bday party but will return any night of the week.  

The staff is really, really nice, has absolutely no attitude and took really good care of us!  The owner who we kept calling Mama gave out jello shots and then insisted we sing Karaoke (OK, twist our drunken arms!).  If you like to dance they've got that going on too.

The decor is comfortable and the location is great.  You can order food across the street at New Hong Kong and they will bring it over to you at the bar...eventually.  Beware, it took an hour or more to get our food but hey, I'm not reviewing the restaurant.  ;)

If cheap drinks, happy people and delivered food aren't enough for you, there's a Shao Lin martial arts school across the street that practices in the alley in front of the bar for added entertainment!

If you're into big fun with a great crowd, this could easily become your new favorite place!
author: Jon B.

description: Came here for a friend's birthday Saturday night! The bar filled up by 12am! Good prices on drinks and a nice little dance area with tons of seating! The area wasn't that difficult to find parking but it just takes some circling. The bartender was super nice and attentive! Overall, I enjoyed my time there drinking and catching up with old friends.
author: Betty P.

description:
Friendly and Comfortable hang-out!  Could easily become my next "Cheers".

Cute and amicable bartenders & waitresses.
author: Richard C.

description:
A friend was coming here for happy hour on Friday so he brought along a group of us to join him. This place is tucked away in an alley near Chinatown. You won't really find it unless you're actually looking for it. (Between Montgomery & Kearny, on Commercial street)

This place is a little divey but has a lot of character. It's not a big place but also not really crowded. Despite that, it's easy to have a good time here. The staff is friendly, helpful and quick with service. There's a DJ in the back playing a variety of music (you can also requests songs which my friends did). Nearby there's a food bar with small snacks for FREE that you can munch on while you drink with some friends.

Definitely a good place - friendly crowd, good bartenders and DJ.
author: Angela K.

description:
Went here for a birthday celebration - it isnt a packed bar which makes it a lot more fun.

They played AWESOME music and the best part of the night was when the owner came out from behind the bar to dance and take shots with us!

Really fun bar overall, great people, great music.
author: Jenna L.

description:
With the economy at its worst since the Great Depression...It's time to have a drink.  And better make that a cheap drink.  For those who are in search of a bar that doesn't perform some serious liposuction on the wallet, EZ5 delivers on all counts.

The spot is in a somewhat hidden alley way near the Chinatown/FiDi juncture.  Slightly divy but with a nice little Hawaiian-style twist.  Stopped by here on a weeknight with my cousin and my buddy after eating at R&G just kitty corner to the place...totally mellow and turned out perfect for just chilling out.  We liked the good drink selection...and I'm certain my cousin really liked the self-serve snack mix station where the bartender kindly instructed him, "Don't get no maw den you can eat!!!

All in all, great spot to check out...Get those much-needed drinks without doing too much damage to the good ol' wallet.
author: Justin L.

description:
So after the Yelp Pley party, my boyfriend and I set out to make a lil trouble in SF.  We looked around for some open clubs without much luck as it was a weekday but then, stumbled upon EZ5.   Yes, it looked deserted.  Yes, it looked small.  Yes, it was still fun for us.  

We went in and ordered a couple of drinks.  They were STRONG and reasonably priced... very strong.  Did I mention strong? haha  Anyway, there was a group of people at the bar that seemed to be regulars.   There was also a guy spinning some pretty fun tunes from the 80's and 90's.  It also has ample seating and a nice open set-up.  

At one point, I got up and wandered around the bar to look around.  My boyfriend was still sitting at our table so one of the bar guys came over to him, gave him a 'high-five' and said something to the effect of 'good job!'.  When I got back, my boyfriend told me what happened so I went over to the guy's girlfriend, gave her a high-five and told her good job!  LoL

I'd come back.  All in all it was a pretty fun stop.  

See ya there!
author: Susan D.

description:
So a few of us decided to come here for Thirsty Thursdays after work. It's a fairly new concept and we all wanted to go somewhere near FiDi. Along comes Yelp and bam, found a random spot. 
The place is... very orange! It's on a side street so it might be hard to find, but I like that. Their happy hour specials are pretty good. The music was interesting. More like DJ-press-play-on-my-ipod. There is a DJ booth though, so maybe they have DJ parties sometimes. Not very crowded, but we were there early. It's a good spot to be able to catch up with pals over drinks. I'll keep this in our Thirsty rotations.
author: Dee D.

description: This bar Is the place to go!  The bartenders cam and gain hooked it up!  I will absolutely be coming back!!
author: Andy R.

description:
Nicer looking dive bar. Cheap drinks during happy hour and decent service except for the tall girl. We had a yelp deal for some shots and instead of just letting us use the damn thing for all the shots. She literally made us all go on, check in and still didn't even use the coupon. I don't get it, i'm all for checking in and what not but if you're going to make us go through the trouble of bringing up the coupon for you then actually use it. If you go to the bar, go to the dude, pours much better. Tall Korean chick "depending" on the time of month if she's nice or not. This time, it was the wrong time! 
You do get to bring in your own food which is nice!
author: Sean S.

description:
I went to EZ5 for the first time last night; it was tucked away in one of San Francisco's little alley ways and sadly unless you were directed to it, you may not readily find it.   So here goes - it is between Montgomery & Kearny, a block away from The Transamerica Pyramid.  

It was a quiet night but I had a ball.  The DJ, Benson was terrific (he is there on Thursdays) - one of the review stated that one of the DJs played Taylor Swift (though I am not a fan), I loved the fact that he played music that everyone loved mixed with classic dance and rap.

Somethings, you just want a friendly crowd and a cool barkeep (her name is Tu), who simply serves me a drink and I don't need to develope a special "attention-getting-skill" in order to be served.  

Poser Bars can be so tiring.  This was just a fun night after work with friends, a cool crowd doesn't have to try that hard.
author: Paula M.

description:
I had a liquid cocaine shot, 2 gusinesses, 2 car boms, 1 markers mark, and some more and yet I was only buzzed. I'd give this place a 4 if the drinks were a little more stiff. It almost made me think that shot of Jamieson was watered down. Oh well. It's was pretty chill for haloween. The music was a little bit of everything (like holy cow minus the lameness of that place).

It was a bit amsuing to myself when they didn't even bother checking my ID.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
Someone asked me the other night, "why do you like EZ5?" 
 I think of it kind of like an Asian Cheers bar. For some reason there is always a familiar face here.  If you come with a group of friends, you can pretty much take over the whole place.

The staff is friendly and the prices are decent. Wow, can that lady bartender drink!

There's a DJ there, and the last time I went, there was plenty of Michael Jackson = WIN!

Decent parking situation

Located near plenty of affordable hotels, meaning you can stumble to a room instead of worrying about driving or DDs.

Clean bathroom. A separate one for women/men. Yay!

Cheap jello shots.

You can bring in your own snacks no problem.

Lychee martini is the most delicious nectar of the gods. GET IT!
author: Krista F.

description:
Pros: Friendly quick service, small but spacious venue, DJ and dance floor.

Cons: Kind of dead and hard to find.

Overall: It'd be a great local neighborhood bar for a daily drink or a place to easily have your own private party.
author: Binh D.

description: WTF HAPPENED LAST NIGHT?! Thanks to MaryAnne's and Jenny's bartending skills I have lost 2 of my friends. Want to make your night SUPER MEMORABLE?! Try MaryAnne's Specialty "Poison Apple". Prince Charming can face rape you and that won't even wake you from the comatose state you will end up in. So thank you EZ5...you have successfully made my 2nd night here in San Francisco forgettable...now to look for 2 of my Asian friends...
author: Simeon M.

description:
You got to love a place that passes out free jello shots for the heck of it.

It's not in Chinatown. It's not in the FiDi. It's just a cool dive bar in the Twilight Zone with great service cool crowd and chill vibe. 

They serve up beer by the liter, cool happy hour specials and they even make microwave popcorn on occasion.  

Its a mix crowd of after work FiDi types and Chinatown locals mingling together -- yes its cheesey but hip.

Drink Up!
author: G R.

description: We came here with a big group and got a table with couches around it and that was sweet! Loud DJ music on a Friday night but not very crowded so it felt odd. The decorations reminded me of the 90s - zebra wallpaper, strobe lights, and the entrance had beads hanging that you had to part to get through. Also a pac man machine was a plus. All in all, pretty average.
author: Justine S.

description:
I have been in here 3-4 times now. The last time a bunch of folks from work came out. As we walked in, the DJ was playing funky cold medina. And then later the beastie boys. And they had some random bowl game on. The happy hour was good- I think they had $3.00 Sierra Nevadas? 

The outside of this place looks very unappetising- since there are like 3 happy ending massage places around it, I thought it might have been a strip club or something...
author: Jim B.

description:
I got me some French kisses tonight!  And mmm hmmm dey was go-od!   

EZ5's French Kiss has intrigue, chambord, orange vodka, and pineapple juice in it.  And if you go during happy hour 4pm - 8pm, it's $1 off.  They also have beer for $3.

A good after work place to unwind with peeps.  Yes, it is divey and has a basement, slightly cheesy feel to it but it's comfy, not too crowded, and not a meat market.  Also, they had some good tunes spinning.  

I've also been here late in the evening (post dinner in Chinatown) and it was pretty dead.  

The best thing about EZ5?  THEY HAVE A MS. PAC-MAN VIDEO GAME!  And Ms. Pac Man is the best video game ev-er, though hard to play if one has had too many French kisses.  (Not that I would know, I'm jest saying...)
author: Amy C.

description:
Did I literally just step into a hole in the wall? That's what it felt like when I went down to this unknown alley and walked into a bar blasting Lady Gaga and an old Asian lady dancing by herself in the middle. I felt like I was drunk already by the sight before me.

I went here for a friend's birthday party and it was relatively empty until we occupied the space. Who needs to pay for bottle service and a VIP spot when you can come here? No velvet rope needed. The bar seems like it's family owned and very friendly. The prices are pretty cheap for a downtown bar and they make 'em pretty stiff. So yay for getting your money's worth! Also the DJ is one of the owner's sons and it's easy to request your favorite song to dance to drunk and there's ample amount of room to bust out your moves.

Overall nice place to grab a drink if you don't want a crowded atmosphere and need room to dance. Friendly staff and parking isn't a hassle late at night. Very discreet location so you can miss it while walking but there's usually a bouncer at the door to flag you down.
author: Leslie K.

description:
It was around 10 PM on Saturday night and was I visiting friends in the bay area. After dinner, we wanted to find a place we could have a few drinks and  get caught up.

Schroeder's was down the street from my hotel, so we walked in there. Nein, we're closing for the night. OK, we walk past Harrington's Bar and Grill. Really bad, loud, cover-band rock is blaring out of it. No thanks.

Finally, we see a restaurant worker having a puff in a alley. "Yo, any dive bars around here where a guy can get a cold one?" "Yeah, go up the street, make a right, another right into the alley and you'll find EZ5." Cool!

From the outside EZ5 looks like a dive bar, but when you walk in, you see it's been redone in a 70s lounge style. This will work.

A DJ was playing some mellow hip-hop, but it wasn't too loud that you couldn't have a conversation. The waitress was prompt and friendly and the drinks were reasonably priced. 

It seemed slow for a Saturday night, but the night was still young. I wouldn't have any problem coming back here.
author: Jim K.

description:
EZ-5 you can do no wrong. 

Nearly two years later and I'm still frequenting this place whether for casual engagement celebrations, welcome back parties, or birthdays. The older I get, the more I'm inclined to places that are just laidback, no fuss, and EZ:) Our gang headed here to celebrate our friend's bday and had a blast. I'm not gonna lie, I'm a little jealous that mama (the owner) gave her a snappy looking black EZ5 tank...but I think I'll survive. Dancing the night away to old school hip hop, and my favorite top 40 definitely helped. Cheers to EZ5!
author: Irene B.

description:
Spur of the moment, headed there with a girlfriend after work on a Friday.  In an obscure area where the financial district ends (and shuts down after 5:00 pm on a Friday) and North China Beach starts - this small hole in the wall bar inspires with its hip music and diverse crowd.  Hoochie little Asian girls tend the bar (I don't mean that in a mean way, I used to be one afterall) with a full bar and some decent mixed drinks.  

Seems almost family owned as I saw plenty of frat boy like guys hugging and flirting with who could only be the mamma boss.  After this, I went home, called my mom and dad and told them that they should open a bar and let me be the bartender. I'll definitely be back ...
author: Kathleen W.

description:
I'm kind of in love with this bar - walking in, it looks random and funny, kind of like a pimped out rec room in someone's basement.  Painted red/orange walls, assorted chairs/couches, little glow lights all around.  

We grabbed a seat by the window and the very sweet server came by to take our order.  It was happy hour, so most drinks were only $3, good value!  Service was really quick, efficient, and friendly, and my partner appreciated the free pretzel munchies.  

Crowd was a bit random - scattered groups that mostly looked like office after-work happy hours.  There was a live DJ, which was really nice and she played a great mix of current hits and old favorites.  Overall a fun joint - I'd come back for happy hour or even on a weekend.
author: Jaimie M.

description:
Great place to go for cheap drinks and a place to hang out with your friends. sometimes EZ5 can be a little dead (not as crowded) but then there are nights like last night where it was popping. 

good drinks, good music & definitely no cover and dres code.
author: Carol Y.

description:
Came here on Saturday night. 

I stayed long enough for 2 drinks, I don't plan on coming back, unless I'm coming of a short party bus.
author: Juana S.

description:
EZ5 is freaking awesome. This is the best happy hour -- it lasts from 5pm to 8pm with beer AND wine for only $3! Some places only have happy hours from 2pm to 5pm, ummm... who gets off work in the middle of the afternoon? Thank you EZ5!

I usually can't stand the DJs in bars (see my review of Vertigo). They tend to be corny as hell but this DJ at EZ5 knew what he was doing and doing it well. I know when it's a good night out when I wake up the next day and my legs and back are aching from dancing. This little bar has a lot going on for it!

I'm going back again, this time I'll bring my girlfriends for inexpensive drinks and good music. :)
author: Frances L.

description:
Hands down, my favoritest bar/lounge in the Bay, bar none. Keep in mind this is coming from a career non-drinker who just so happens to hang out with a lot of party peeps. And both ends of the spectrum - from the crazy party animals to the prudies like me agree - EZ5 hits the spot! Every single birthday party from my circle of friends and associates always ends up here as the final stop to cap off the evening, and for good reason.

Ladies, are you sick of the sleazed out "dance clubs" that play nothing but the likes of Souljah Boy, Plies, and whatever else mainstream crap is on the airwaves today? To make matters even worse, the patrons look like they got lost on their way to the "Growing up Gotti" lookalike contest, or think they are starring in the latest season of "The Ultimate Fighter?" Well, you are in luck, and your salvation goes by the name of EZ5.

Not only does the DJ bypass all of the current mainstream hit pop, but mixes in a good blend of golden era hip hop and gangsta rap, new wave, new jack swing, and even hair metal. Where else can you hear the likes of New Edition, Dove Shack, Bon Jovi, Chi Ali, Stevie B., Debarge, Guns 'n Roses, Positive K, New Order, Pharcyde, Ozzy, and Color Me Badd all back to back? What's more, the DJ's have zero attitude, and are open to requests. They are more equivalent to the downhome DJ's you would find at a house party.

Tucked away in a nondescript corner of Chinatown, you would never find EZ5 unless someone brought you here. As a matter of fact, I had been strolling by this very spot ad nauseum since I was a wee lad, and I would never have known there was a bar on this tiny alley. When you first bring your friends here, they will all moan with a collective, "You have GOT to be KIDDING ME!!!" when first catching a glimpse of the location, with the low key exterior and circa 70's neon sign. However, once they walk through that hallowed corridor, the party's on!

The owners are a super cool middle aged Chinese couple, the type whom you would never associate with operating a bar - a kick arse one at that. My group has become quite acquainted with them by now, and they always take good care of us. That's the number one sign of a good bar when the regulars are treated like family. 

Above all, nowhere to be found at EZ5 are the "Growing Up Daisy" casting call rejects. Nothing but classy, well-mannered, and typically more educated peeps here. After all, this is where I come, right?  ;-)  Furthermore, unlike most bars/lounges/clubs, which neatly fit into one category or the other, but not all three, EZ5 has a little bit of each. Feel like just chillin' at the bar, but not dancing? Maybe more in the mood to chop it up with your group of ten friends in a booth? Perhaps fancy to shake what yo mama gave ya? Do one, two, or all three simultaneously at the almighty EZ5.

When it comes to nightlife in the Bay, there are only two categories in my book. Either it's EZ... or sleazy. The choice is yours.
author: Eric W.

description:
We went to EZ5 at the end of a very long and adventurous day.  We were pushing our luck in terms of parking, since we found pretty pimp parking almost everywhere we strolled to.  Good thing the luck continued through to this place.

I felt a bit dizzy when I walked in.  The disco ball is very distracting and gives the bar a very 80s feel but with new millennium pricing.

I like all the couches.  I like that our party was pretty much half the clientèle that night.  I like that the restroom smells fresh and is extremely clean.  I like that I used to work with one of the bartenders back in the day (yay reunion!).  I like I like I like.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I always enjoy EZ5 when I'm there.  The bar staff is great, and the drinks are even better as long as you know what you like.  I had a mean Long Island Iced Tea there last Friday in addition to a few shots.  Stop by and check out the haps if you have a chance.  Highly recommended.
UPDATE: This has become my favorite bar.  The people are always very friendly and everyone always has such a good time.  You owe it to yourself to check out EZ5 soon and experience it often.
author: Jonathon J.

description: I came here for a friends birthday and probably wouldn't come back again.  It is a bar to go to before you go the real bar.  It is strangely styled with african design (keep in mind an asian family appears to own it) and house music played by a DJ.  I was definitely ready to leave at 10 which we ended up doing.
author: Andrea G.

description: Cheap drinks and it's right by my office. The waitress remembers me and always has my refill ready! They have free chip usually on hand.  It is right in between China town and the Fidi.  You do get a mix of people at times.
author: John R.

description: Nice and quiet place. I come here because I'm Chinese.
author: Doug F.

description: I've been here twice and it never fails me! The drinks are cheap and it tastes really good! They have almost every drink you can think of! I especially love their Winter Moon, Bedtime Kiss and Mojito! I really enjoy being in this place because it's a nice place to chill, TV, music is great, and the staff are really nice!
author: Claireace M.

description: If you are in search of a bar to hang out in and drink that is fine.  But if you want to go to a bar for the karaoke, this is NOT the place.  The English song list is minimal and the song book is not organized at all.  It took me about 20 minutes to find a song that we saw when we first opened the book after we turned a few pages.  We thought we were going crazy and it actually disappeared from the book!  The "KJ" was obviously the owner or a family member. She seemed nice but did not understand or speak any English at all.  She just laughed and nodded whenever I asked her a question.  My daughter asked her if they had "Before He Cheats" which is pretty much a karaoke staple and she had no idea if they had it or if it was even a song!  She just kept pointing at the mish-mash song book.  When I finally picked a song, she put it in the machine, handed me the mike, and then proceeded to try to hand some random regular guy at the bar another mike to "help me sing".  I was walking out the door before the song even ended only to find myself inundated with skeevy cab drivers waiting to take advantage of this out of towner to get me back to my hotel.  It was a nightmare, truly.  BTW....if you sing here, don't expect to sing your song, they give out mikes to every drunk at the bar to sing with you.  Just a very weird experience.  Not a karaoke bar.
author: Shelly G.

description:
If it was not for my friend's 21st birthday, I would of never heard of this place. It's literally located in an alley.

The place was pretty dead until a group of 10+ of us came in and basically took over the place. It was just our group and a couple of other people. 

Maybe it was just the night we on but it's a pretty intimate place if you just want a place to drink with your friends outside of your house without the disturbance of other people. 

Regardless, you can have fun here. It just depends on the people you go with. 

Oh, and kudos the the chips and snacks they give out to the drunk asses who needed to sober up. =p
author: Viel A.

description:
The most amazing aquarium skeleton I have ever seen lives here. Walk to the back of the room, just next to the bathroom and stand in front of the illuminated aquarium to watch this little bony dude bop his whole underwater body and his skinny outstretched arm exactly in sync with the beat of whatever Kanye/Justin Timberlake/Bel Biv DeVoe song is bumpin' under the disco ball. I think he may be wearing sunglasses but those could also be his dark eye sockets. And that perma-grin on his face says, "Good times" like nothing else. My friend Erin and I invented a new dance called "The Skeleton" after him. 

Added bonus: if you find yourself caught in a vaguely unsettling conversation with a stranger who may be hitting on you and keeps trying to put his hand on your lower back, just look around for whoever might be drinking out of the Animal House beer helmet and say urgently, "Oh, I have to go watch that guy do that! Sorry!" and then rush over to enjoy the spectacle. 

I took one star away because some people were complaining that the drinks were weak and the soda was stale, but I didn't really notice. The discovery of the skeleton dance kind of took away my ability to properly judge anything else.
author: Katrina D.

description:
I got invited to a birthday at EZ5 Chinatown. I thought to myself, this must be ghetto. It was actually pretty cool. There's no cover charge. It is pretty easy to get a table even on a Friday/Saturday night. It is just kinda small and they have the bar and dance floor smashed in the same area. The drinks are pretty cheap and it seems hard to get buzz on a drink or shot here. 
I think this beats standing outside in line at a club in the freezing SF weather @ 11 on a Saturday so you can be physically disturbed by the many human bodies in which you realized is 5 years younger than you. Ew...! Yes, I've been there. 

EZ5 is more of a just hang out place for working people.
author: Hungry D.

description: I do miss going here. After a long week of working in the Financial District there was nothing like blowing off a little steam at EZ5. Friendly staff, interesting clientele, just a great neighborhood feel.
author: Scott D.

description:
This place is reasonably divey and is a welcomed respite from the other lame FiDi happy hour scenes. I coaxed some coworkers, who have it got it hot and heavy for Harrington's, to this place and everyone loved it..

Cheap drinks during happy hour, and they're cool with you bringing outside food in - Tokyo Express sushi two blocks away? The staff is super accommodating, no matter how confusing and crazy the orders get, and there's a DJ.

I will be back.
author: Alex V.

description:
My boyfriend celebrated his birthday here last weekend.  It's a great spot to hang out, chill, and get hammered.  It's a block away from Chinatown so we parked here http://www.sfpsg.com/.  It's $2.50/hr. We came early and walked around Chinatown a bit.  Though, if you come later in the evening, free metered parking I heard from an SF native.  

If you plan on bringing a larger party, I recommend calling to reserve a little section, we weren't aware you could do that so we ended up standing around.  

I would recommend Day Off (Absolute Citron, fresh lemons, sweet & sour and Ginger Ale) and Lychee Dawn (Mango Rum, Pineapple Juice, and 7-up).  They're both light, but they taste DELICIOUS!

I took one star away because it got really really really warm in there, especially towards the later hours when it got busier.
author: Lesley M.

description:
This is an interesting place.  Went looking for Ginger Trois, because i had never been there before, probably because i can NEVER find it...so again, after searching for a mysterious bar that i can hope to make it to one day, my friend Paul directed us into here.

Beanbags, couches, retro chairs, and one hand chair that i got lucky enough to sit in covered the place.  It wasn't very busy so we got a great spot and got comfortable.  They also had service at the tables, so it made our laziness work for us.  I'm pretty sure we got free edamame at the table too, cuz it appeared and i don't think anyone ordered it...so thats cool too.
The drinks were priced what drinks should be priced without making me really angry, and the red lighting gave this financial district on the edge of china town bar the unique feel that i like when walking into a bar.  Is it divey?  Is it hip?  Is it just what it is?  I don't really know.  Maybe on a busier day, who knows.
author: Lauren F.

description:
San Francisco is the Freakout role-playing capital of the world. 

Yes, people say they come here for the beauty, but this is a big pile of steaming poop. 

We all know why we really came here: it's the only place in the US where you can act out ANY twisted, parentally-induced, peer group-inflamed lifestyle fantasy you want, and have (a) a local cottage industry to provide you with literature, advice, clothing, accessories, etc., and (b) friends who accept your fantasy, mainly because when they're done listening they get to give you an earful about theirs.

EZ5 is where you go when you want to pretend you are in a Steely Dan or Donald Fagen song. It's got all the elements of their best work:

- It's a little obscure, tucked down a dark alleyway in Chinatown
- It's hip and dysfunctional at the same time
- It's warm and dark at the same time
- There are elements both exotic and banal
- and finally, a story unfolds, usually with sordid elements.

I've been here three or four times over the last three years: the last time I came here with four drunk friends the bartender decided we were good people and started feeding us IMMENSE amounts of liquor, punctuated by statements such as "I GRANDMA! SERIOUSLY! I HAVE THREE GRANDCHILDREN!!", and "C'MON!! YOU DO SHOT WITH GRANDMA!!!" 

At least one member of the group was sucking Grandma's fingers before we staggered out of EZ5 that night. For a moment I felt like I could have been some 1930's sailor careening down the Bund back to his ship.

So, um, I have a confession to make.

I quoted Steely Dan in my yearbook.
author: Karsten P.

description:
Went here for a friends birthday.  I love the tacky 70's theme with the decor and the seating, overall a pretty fun atmosphere.  Drank more then I care to remember here...  Last thing I remember is meet with one of the owners of the shop and we were trading shots of vodka, to which she would mock me by saying it's water and she could do it all night.  Needless to say, I'm sure we all know what will happen when you get called out by an Asian woman to a drinking contest, no one wins in the end...  Sigh...  Any case, people may think it looks seedy, I actually like how it is cozy and dim, kinda nice escape from a hard days work.  They have happy hour from 4pm to 8 pm, and no door covers, always a plus.  I have always had a good time whenever I come here.

Oh and stay here long enough or come often enough, they will break out the jello shots...  It's just a really fun atmosphere and evening whenever I come here with some friends.
author: Chris T.

description:
let's be very frank about this place:  it's not a pub.  for some that's a bad thing, for others it's a welcomed breath of fresh air.

it's kinda dark inside, it's nestled in a relatively obscure alley way, and not the best english is spoken by the staff.  i call this "character".

i read some of the reviewers' comments regarding the bad food.  first off, it's not that bad considering it's free.  secondly, IT'S A BAR!  if you want good food i suggest other establishments commonly referred to as "restaurants".  

it's located on the edge of the financial distract, and given the number of pub and pub-like joints in the area, this place rocks.  it's unassuming, unpretentious, $3 happy hour drink specials, Guinness on tap, friendly staff, awesomely bad neon lights, galaxia/mrs pac man arcade game... i could go on forever, but i won't.  you just have to experience it for yourself.
author: vuForce Fresh n.

description:
3.5 stars - 4 stars for the vibe and 3 stars for the drinks.  

Not sure how long this place has been here but I love the location.  If you are hungry, just go across to HK Menu for some quick grub.  

Hubby remembers it from his younger days when it had a pool table but I've never been.  It has the feel of a Chinatown bar with an updated decor and lounge feel.  The dj is to the left as you enter followed by a large open space with low seatings and tables with the bar across.  There is additional seating immediately to your right as you enter with benches and low tables.  We sat there and stretched our legs.  I didn't notice they have sangria and ordered the EZ5 cosmo ($7 less $1 during HH) with Stoli, cherry juice, triple sec and fresh lime.  The drink was flat and too sweet.  Hubby had the Sierra Nevada, that's the HH beer at $3 as suggested by the waitress.  We initally started a tab with a cc ($20 minimum charge) but ended up paying cash after 1 drink.  

So HH is 4-8pm with $1 off special cocktails, $3 wine and Sierra.  

We liked the music, it was a mix of Old School, freestyle and dance.  The dj switches at 9:00 or 9:30pm.  We shall return.
author: Gloria H.

description: Non-obnoxious financial district bar.
author: Patrick S.

description:
I came here for a little birthday party, and it's such a hidden gem. 
The staff here are very nice and friendly. The DJ was great. He mixed in old school with some new hip hop. 
The drinks are awesome and strong. Try the "Three Day Weekend" - super girly drink, and you'll be wishing you had a three day weekend.

The owner was sitting at the bar with some patrons, playing dice. She was really welcoming.  This place is so cozy and relaxting that I think next time grandma and I have a girls' night, I'll bring her here.

Extra points for the well maintained fish tank.
author: Vanessa W.

description: It's our go to spot for HH here at the office. It's perfect for us. They play today's hits (sprinkled w/some '90s). The ambiance is pretty chill. It's really small but there's a little lounge area, seating at the bar and a dance floor. The bartenders are friendly and "Mama" is really cool! Worth checking out w/a group of coworkers or friends!
author: Elle V.

description:
If it wasn't for my friend's friend's b'day, I doubt I would ever go here on my own. It's just a little bit out of my way. 

I love the big couches and the drinks are pretty reasonable I'd say, but nothing memorable. Actually, yeah...just leave it that way.
author: Perry S.

description:
I usually like to go out for good wine, nice plates, or an overpriced cocktail.  However, EZ5 has converted me into a lover of the dive bar.  $3 sierra pints, free pretzels (and popcorn too, if the owner knows you...yeah, my coworkers and i are that special), goldfish, and chips.  

its a bit dangerous that this place is right around the corner from my office.  

-1 star for not wanting to go there when its still light out.
author: Timothy S.

description:
Never thought I'd be drinking it up in Chinatown on a Saturday but EZ5 is a pretty chill and fun place to meet up and socialize. The place got a little throwback Chinese theme that makes you feel like you're in a scene from some 1970's Hong Kong film. 

There's a bar that the runs on the side with a pagoda-inspired design. In front, an open forum for people to hangout and gather so it maximizes the little space it has. Not exactly a crowd-drawing area or venue, but I think that's what attracts people to come so they can avoid the tools that invade the night scene.
author: Ed L.

description:
First time coming here a few night ago. I was already buzzed from a previous bar, but I must say, this place is nice. Once I stepped in, the place had a live DJ spinning and people just chilling. Nothing too roudy or funky. Everything was nice and clean, which is a plus. 

Once we walked in, my friends and I ordered our drinks and BAM, a arm shoots out in front of us and hands us a bowl of peanuts. Peanuts? Free? and we didn't have to ask? I'm loving this place. Can't go wrong with munchies while you drink you sorrows away.

So I ordered another drink, Long Island. I drank maybe half, went to the bathroom and came back with a full glass of Long Island. My friends told the bartender there weren't enough booze in my drink as a joke, and he re-filled it with more. Wow, who would do that? Thats an extra star. Good drinks, nice atmosphere, chill place. Nice family business. I gotta support the small businesses.
author: David L.

description:
It's so easy to underestimate how a night is going to go at this place. One thinks they're starting with the "warm-up-band" of bars before you head out to the "biggers and betters," casually enjoying a Ciroc Greyhound. Next thing you know it's the main event, it's close to closing time, and yer asking yourself "WTF am I still doing here?" while making a Last Call plea for another "Ciroc" ... in Jubaca-speak, with the bartender thinking you've asked for Crackrock.

I've had some great but strange nights here. Two with Big V and one with GoLightly, who can put Ciroc Hounds away like she was eating Bearded Papa's cream puffs. The owner feels her dancin' shoes come on about 11. That's just about when the joint gets hoppin'..with dj's spinnin' House and people playing PacMan or talkin' over libations. 

Four shurikens, because the place has character.
author: Johnny C.

description:
A- OK!

Fun, fun place located in an alley off Kearny.  They apparently have their share of regulars who come in looking for a good time.

My friends introduced me to this place, which I would never have found it if weren't for them.  Don't expect them to make you anything more complicated than a lychee martini and you'll have a good time.
author: Dave N.

description:
Honestly I had pretty low expectations for this dive bar since it's located in Chinatown. It definitely beat all of my expectations. It has GREAT music, cute bartenders (girls) and pretty cheap alcohol. We basically sat here for  7 hours a couple of weekends ago, on a saturday night, because the music was too good and we didn't want to leave! :) 

After 9pm there's live DJs and they played all of my favorite music from Journey to the current hip hop songs! They also accommodated my song requests (even tho I know most DJs HATE that!).

I'll definitely be back here again!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Do you remember when you were little and you used to watch episodes of Twilight Zone and being creeped out and uneasy but not knowing why?

EZ5 had that effect on me.  

The 70's couches, wicker chairs, cloth ottomans and lights, bamboo and weird tiki decorations along with the greasy yet stale tasting Costco Chinese appetizers in the back, totally weirded me out.

Bartenders sucked big time, DJ was a non-entity since it wasn't loud enough to drown out the convo's in the bar.  

Weird over 40 crowd.  I felt like I was drinking in front of a bunch of my mom's friends and that they would tell her that I'm a drunk.  Total randomness all round the bar.  So strange.  So very, very strange.

Do dew do dew Do dew do dew......You have entered the Booze Twilight Zone.
author: Jay H.

description: Great small bar and the music is fantastic . They are so friendly and they make great drinks. The Dj is great !!!
author: P C.

description:
what happened to this great happy hour haunting ground? my co-workers could not believe the lack of attention to drink detail and service. 

and what happened to the great vibe with the djs? there was one who played some great 70s and 80s tracks for us old timers on mondays but from what i heard he is not here anymore. 

anybody know where he is at now? please let us know and we'll be there for happy hour.
author: Jessie M.

description:
What a great happy hour spot on the cusp of the Financial District and Chinatown.  It is hip without being annoying and it isn't filled with a bunch of ties.  The decor is loungy and inviting and the place just rocks a unique vibe. 

The woman running the joint is both warm and no-nonsense.  When a group of four of us went in on a Friday at 5:30 for happy hour it was pretty crowded with no seats (table or bar) in sight.  Standing room only.  We were hoping to imbibe while sitting rather than standing, so we were facing a big dilemma.  As we were scoping the scene, the owner came out of the wood works.  Sensing that we were on the verge of leaving, she came over to us and asked how many we were.  She motioned to some guy who brought us a table and four tiny cushioned stools.  Our hearts were won over.

We enjoyed a round of $1 jello shots and a few rounds of $3 Sierra's.   And if you sit at a table, a totally efficient cocktail waitress comes around to take your drink order, so you really can just max and relax and your drinking desires will be catered to with the quickness.  The cocktail choices are impressively distinct and averagely priced.

The DJ spinning the tunes gets the party started early and was already in full effect when we arrived at 5:30.

And there is free food!  Not just little nibbles like peanuts and goldfish, which are welcome additions in their own right.  But I am talking edamame, pot stickers, mini spring rolls, cheese, salami, crackers, cubed meat, fried chicken wings -- the works. 

EZ5 is a fun place to get the weekend started!  And I am going to have to be tapping into its happy hour magic more often.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Ezzzzieee, breeeziiiiie!

Oh, how I love thee!  This is one of my most favorite bars in the city.  Its like the Asian Cheers hang-out!  Mama, Cam (the owner couple) really know how to throw it down..and will likely try to drink you under the table.

The place as a certain character to it.  I can't quite put my finger to it, but I like that we can have a 'wife-beater aka tank top' with sweats party and still have fun!  No need to dress up.  The music is usually wicked with hip-hop and drinks are really reasonable.  And if the owners like you they'll give you some jello shots on the house!  The restrooms are key which is also money.

I can't recall all the number of times I've been here with all my good buddies.  Always a blast!  I've met so many of my good friends here..and we almost NEVER walk out straight.  Sometimes it could be dead but that's ok.  It just make the setting feel like you own the bar and the owners are so accommodating.  It's so eeeezzzzz you have to check it out.  

I love you MAMA!  Best bar.
author: Yup S.

description:
I liked EZ5, I was turned on to if from Johnny, founder of Fun, Free, Cheap S.F. He hosted a party here a few months ago and the place was packed. I'm sure EZ5 welcomed this event with open arms, I'm not sure how busy they usually get otherwise.

It's nestled in Chinatown, on the border of the Financial District in a small alley. I might not have ever known of or found this place if I hadn't been invited. And, I'm glad I was.

The place is small, comfortable and offers interesting and random decor. The drinks were good and the prices were reasonable. The staff was nice, especially since they were slammed. Often times service levels suffer when establishments are overwhelmed. But not EZ5.
